title: Avatar
description: Display user profile pictures and initials with the Avatar component.

body.raw:
# Avatar The Avatar component displays user profile pictures, icons, or initials in a circular or rounded container. ## Import ```tsx import { Avatar } from '@flexi-ui/avatar' ``` ## Usage ### Basic ```tsx ``` ### With Initials When no image is provided, the Avatar displays initials: ```tsx ``` ### Sizes Avatar comes in multiple sizes: ```tsx ``` ## API ### Avatar Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------|------|---------|-------------| | src | `string` | - | The image source URL | | alt | `string` | - | Alternative text for the image | | name | `string` | - | Name to generate initials from | | size | `sm \| md \| lg` | `md` | Size of the avatar | | radius | `none \| sm \| md \| lg \| full` | `full` | Border radius | | color | `default \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| error` | `default` | Color theme | | isBordered | `boolean` | `false` | Whether to show a border | | isDisabled | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the avatar is disabled | | showFallback | `boolean` | `true` | Show fallback when image fails to load | | fallback | `ReactNode` | - | Custom fallback content | | classNames | `object` | - | Custom classes for slots | ### Slots - **base** - The main avatar wrapper - **img** - The image element - **fallback** - The fallback content (initials or icon) - **icon** - The fallback icon ## Examples ### Bordered Avatar ```tsx ``` ### Avatar Group Display multiple avatars together: ```tsx
``` ### Custom Fallback ```tsx import { User } from 'lucide-react' } /> ``` ### Different Shapes ```tsx ``` ## Accessibility - The Avatar component uses semantic HTML with proper alt text - When using initials, they are announced by screen readers - Supports keyboard navigation when interactive

title: Button
description: A versatile button component with multiple variants and sizes.

body.raw:
# Button Buttons allow users to perform actions and make choices with a single tap. ## Import ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' ``` ## Usage ```tsx ``` ## Variants Buttons come in different variants to suit different use cases: ```tsx
``` ## Colors Choose from various color schemes: ```tsx
``` ## Sizes ```tsx
``` ## API Reference | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------|------|---------|-------------| | color | `default \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| danger` | `default` | The color of the button | | variant | `solid \| bordered \| light \| flat \| ghost` | `solid` | The variant of the button | | size | `sm \| md \| lg` | `md` | The size of the button | | isDisabled | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the button is disabled | | isLoading | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the button is in a loading state |

title: Input
description: Capture user text input with the Input component.

body.raw:
# Input

The Input component allows users to enter text data in forms and interfaces.

## Import

```tsx
import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input'
```

## Usage

### Basic

```tsx
<Input label="Email" placeholder="Enter your email" />
```

### With Description

```tsx
<Input
  label="Email"
  description="We'll never share your email."
  placeholder="Enter your email"
/>
```

### Required

```tsx
<Input
  label="Email"
  placeholder="Enter your email"
  isRequired
/>
```

### Disabled

```tsx
<Input
  label="Email"
  placeholder="Enter your email"
  isDisabled
/>
```

## API

### Input Props

| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| label | `string` | - | Label text |
| placeholder | `string` | - | Placeholder text |
| description | `string` | - | Description text below input |
| errorMessage | `string` | - | Error message to display |
| value | `string` | - | Controlled value |
| defaultValue | `string` | - | Default value |
| type | `string` | `text` | Input type (text, email, password, etc.) |
| size | `sm \| md \| lg` | `md` | Size of the input |
| radius | `none \| sm \| md \| lg \| full` | `md` | Border radius |
| variant | `flat \| bordered \| faded \| underlined` | `flat` | Input variant |
| color | `default \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| error` | `default` | Color theme |
| isRequired | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the input is required |
| isReadOnly | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the input is read-only |
| isDisabled | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the input is disabled |
| isInvalid | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the input is invalid |
| startContent | `ReactNode` | - | Content to display at the start |
| endContent | `ReactNode` | - | Content to display at the end |
| classNames | `object` | - | Custom classes for slots |
| onChange | `(e: ChangeEvent) => void` | - | Change event handler |

### Slots

- **base** - The main wrapper
- **label** - The label element
- **inputWrapper** - The input wrapper
- **input** - The input element
- **description** - The description text
- **errorMessage** - The error message text

## Examples

### Types

```tsx
<Input type="text" label="Text" />
<Input type="email" label="Email" />
<Input type="password" label="Password" />
<Input type="number" label="Number" />
<Input type="url" label="URL" />
```

### Variants

```tsx
<Input variant="flat" label="Flat" />
<Input variant="bordered" label="Bordered" />
<Input variant="faded" label="Faded" />
<Input variant="underlined" label="Underlined" />
```

### Sizes

```tsx
<Input size="sm" label="Small" />
<Input size="md" label="Medium" />
<Input size="lg" label="Large" />
```

### With Icons

```tsx
import { Mail, Lock } from 'lucide-react'

<Input
  label="Email"
  startContent={<Mail className="w-4 h-4" />}
/>

<Input
  type="password"
  label="Password"
  startContent={<Lock className="w-4 h-4" />}
/>
```

### With Validation

```tsx
import { useState } from 'react'

function ValidatedInput() {
  const [value, setValue] = useState('')
  const isInvalid = value.length > 0 && !value.includes('@')

  return (
    <Input
      label="Email"
      value={value}
      onChange={(e) => setValue(e.target.value)}
      isInvalid={isInvalid}
      errorMessage={isInvalid && 'Please enter a valid email'}
    />
  )
}
```

### Password Input

```tsx
import { useState } from 'react'
import { Eye, EyeOff } from 'lucide-react'

function PasswordInput() {
  const [isVisible, setIsVisible] = useState(false)

  return (
    <Input
      label="Password"
      type={isVisible ? 'text' : 'password'}
      endContent={
        <button
          type="button"
          onClick={() => setIsVisible(!isVisible)}
        >
          {isVisible ? <EyeOff /> : <Eye />}
        </button>
      }
    />
  )
}
```

### Controlled Input

```tsx
import { useState } from 'react'

function ControlledInput() {
  const [value, setValue] = useState('')

  return (
    <Input
      label="Name"
      value={value}
      onChange={(e) => setValue(e.target.value)}
    />
  )
}
```

## Accessibility

- Inputs use semantic HTML with proper ARIA attributes
- Labels are automatically associated with inputs
- Error messages are announced to screen readers
- Supports keyboard navigation
- Required fields are properly marked
- Disabled state is properly communicated

title: Link
description: Navigate between pages with the Link component.

body.raw:
# Link

The Link component provides accessible navigation with support for external links and routing libraries.

## Import

```tsx
import { Link } from '@flexi-ui/link'
```

## Usage

### Basic

```tsx
<Link href="/about">About</Link>
```

### External Link

```tsx
<Link href="https://flexiui.com" isExternal>
  Visit FlexiUI
</Link>
```

### With Icon

```tsx
import { ExternalLink } from 'lucide-react'

<Link href="https://flexiui.com" isExternal showAnchorIcon>
  Visit FlexiUI
</Link>
```

## API

### Link Props

| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|------|------|---------|-------------|
| href | `string` | - | URL to navigate to |
| isExternal | `boolean` | `false` | Whether link opens in new tab |
| showAnchorIcon | `boolean` | `false` | Show external link icon |
| isDisabled | `boolean` | `false` | Whether the link is disabled |
| isBlock | `boolean` | `false` | Make link display as block |
| size | `sm \| md \| lg` | `md` | Size of the link |
| color | `foreground \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| error` | `primary` | Color theme |
| underline | `none \| hover \| always \| active \| focus` | `none` | When to show underline |
| as | `ElementType` | `a` | Component to render as |
| className | `string` | - | Additional CSS classes |
| children | `ReactNode` | - | Link content |

## Examples

### Colors

```tsx
<Link href="#" color="foreground">Foreground</Link>
<Link href="#" color="primary">Primary</Link>
<Link href="#" color="secondary">Secondary</Link>
<Link href="#" color="success">Success</Link>
<Link href="#" color="warning">Warning</Link>
<Link href="#" color="error">Error</Link>
```

### Sizes

```tsx
<Link href="#" size="sm">Small</Link>
<Link href="#" size="md">Medium</Link>
<Link href="#" size="lg">Large</Link>
```

### Underline

```tsx
<Link href="#" underline="none">No underline</Link>
<Link href="#" underline="hover">Underline on hover</Link>
<Link href="#" underline="always">Always underlined</Link>
<Link href="#" underline="active">Underline when active</Link>
<Link href="#" underline="focus">Underline on focus</Link>
```

### Block Link

```tsx
<Link href="#" isBlock>
  This link takes up the full width
</Link>
```

### Disabled Link

```tsx
<Link href="#" isDisabled>
  Disabled link
</Link>
```

### With Next.js

```tsx
import NextLink from 'next/link'
import { Link } from '@flexi-ui/link'

<Link as={NextLink} href="/about">
  About
</Link>
```

### With React Router

```tsx
import { Link as RouterLink } from 'react-router-dom'
import { Link } from '@flexi-ui/link'

<Link as={RouterLink} to="/about">
  About
</Link>
```

### With Remix

```tsx
import { Link as RemixLink } from '@remix-run/react'
import { Link } from '@flexi-ui/link'

<Link as={RemixLink} to="/about">
  About
</Link>
```

### Custom Styling

```tsx
<Link
  href="#"
  className="font-bold uppercase"
>
  Custom Link
</Link>
```

## Accessibility

- Links use semantic HTML with proper ARIA attributes
- External links include `rel="noopener noreferrer"` for security
- Disabled links have `aria-disabled` attribute
- Supports keyboard navigation
- Screen readers announce link purpose and destination
- Focus states are clearly visible

title: Spinner
description: Show loading states with the Spinner component.

body.raw:
# Spinner The Spinner component displays a loading indicator to show that content is being loaded or processed. ## Import ```tsx import { Spinner } from '@flexi-ui/spinner' ``` ## Usage ### Basic ```tsx ``` ### With Label ```tsx ``` ### Sizes ```tsx ``` ## API ### Spinner Props | Prop | Type | Default | Description | |------|------|---------|-------------| | size | `sm \| md \| lg` | `md` | Size of the spinner | | color | `current \| white \| default \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| error` | `primary` | Color theme | | label | `string` | - | Label text to display | | labelColor | `foreground \| primary \| secondary \| success \| warning \| error` | `foreground` | Label color | | className | `string` | - | Additional CSS classes | | classNames | `object` | - | Custom classes for slots | ### Slots - **base** - The main wrapper - **wrapper** - The spinner wrapper - **circle1** - First circle - **circle2** - Second circle - **label** - The label element ## Examples ### Colors ```tsx ``` ### Sizes ```tsx ``` ### With Different Label Colors ```tsx ``` ### In a Button ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' ``` ### Full Page Loading ```tsx
``` ### Inline Loading ```tsx
Loading data...
``` ### Card Loading State ```tsx import { Card, CardBody } from '@flexi-ui/card' ``` ### Conditional Loading ```tsx import { useState, useEffect } from 'react' function DataLoader() { const [isLoading, setIsLoading] = useState(true) useEffect(() => { // Simulate data loading setTimeout(() => setIsLoading(false), 2000) }, []) if (isLoading) { return } return
Data loaded!
} ``` ### Custom Styling ```tsx ``` ## Accessibility - Spinners include `role="status"` for screen readers - Loading state is announced to assistive technologies - Labels are properly associated with the spinner - Uses `aria-label` when no visible label is present - Can be used with `aria-live` regions for dynamic content

title: Colors
description: Customize colors in FlexiUI.

body.raw:
# Colors FlexiUI provides a comprehensive color system based on semantic color tokens. ## Semantic Colors FlexiUI uses semantic color names for consistent theming: ### Primary Colors ```tsx ``` ### Status Colors ```tsx ``` ### Neutral Colors ```tsx ``` ## Color Palette The default color palette includes: - **primary**: Main brand color - **secondary**: Secondary brand color - **success**: Success states (#0cce6b) - **warning**: Warning states (#ffc107) - **error**: Error states (#f31260) - **default**: Neutral color ## Customizing Colors ### Via Provider Customize colors through the FlexiUIProvider: ```tsx import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' const theme = { colors: { primary: '#0070f3', secondary: '#7928ca', success: '#0cce6b', warning: '#ffc107', error: '#f31260' } } function App() { return ( {/* Your app */} ) } ``` ### Via Tailwind Config Extend colors in your Tailwind configuration: ```js // tailwind.config.js module.exports = { theme: { extend: { colors: { primary: '#0070f3', secondary: '#7928ca' } } } } ``` ## Color Shades Each semantic color has light and dark variants: ```tsx
Primary
Primary 50%
Primary 20%
``` ## Background and Foreground FlexiUI uses content layers for backgrounds: ```tsx
Content 1
Content 2
Content 3
``` ## Text Colors Use foreground colors for text: ```tsx

Default text

Muted text

Primary text

``` ## Border Colors Apply colors to borders: ```tsx
Divider border
Primary border
``` ## Opacity Control color opacity: ```tsx
10% opacity
50% opacity
90% opacity
``` ## Dark Mode Colors automatically adjust for dark mode: ```tsx
Adapts to light/dark mode
```

title: Dark Mode
description: Implement dark mode in your FlexiUI application.

body.raw:
# Dark Mode FlexiUI provides built-in support for dark mode with automatic theme switching. ## Setup Dark mode works out of the box with the FlexiUIProvider: ```tsx import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' function App() { return ( {/* Your app automatically supports dark mode */} ) } ``` ## Using next-themes For Next.js applications, integrate with `next-themes`: ### Installation ```bash pnpm add next-themes ``` ### Setup Wrap your app with ThemeProvider: ```tsx 'use client' import { ThemeProvider } from 'next-themes' import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' export function Providers({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return ( {children} ) } ``` ## Theme Switcher Create a theme switcher component: ```tsx 'use client' import { useTheme } from 'next-themes' import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Moon, Sun } from 'lucide-react' export function ThemeSwitcher() { const { theme, setTheme } = useTheme() return ( ) } ``` ## Dark Mode Colors Customize colors for dark mode: ```tsx const theme = { colors: { background: { light: '#ffffff', dark: '#000000' }, foreground: { light: '#000000', dark: '#ffffff' }, content1: { light: '#ffffff', dark: '#18181b' } } } ``` ## Using Tailwind Dark Mode Apply dark mode styles with Tailwind: ```tsx
Content that adapts to theme
``` ## System Preference Respect user's system preference: ```tsx {children} ``` ## Force Dark Mode Force dark mode for specific components: ```tsx
``` ## Storage Theme preference is automatically saved to localStorage: ```tsx {children} ``` ## SSR Considerations Prevent flash of wrong theme on initial load: ```tsx import { ThemeProvider } from 'next-themes' export function Providers({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return ( {children} ) } ``` ## Dropdown Theme Selector Create a dropdown for multiple themes: ```tsx 'use client' import { useTheme } from 'next-themes' import { Select, SelectItem } from '@flexi-ui/select' export function ThemeSelector() { const { theme, setTheme } = useTheme() return ( ) } ```

title: Layout
description: Customize the layout system in FlexiUI.

body.raw:
# Layout FlexiUI provides flexible layout utilities built on Tailwind CSS to help you create responsive designs. ## Container Use container utilities for responsive layouts: ```tsx
{/* Your content */}
``` ## Grid System Create grid layouts with Tailwind's grid utilities: ```tsx
Column 1
Column 2
Column 3
``` ## Flexbox Layouts Use flexbox for flexible layouts: ```tsx
Left
Right
``` ## Spacing FlexiUI uses Tailwind's spacing scale: ```tsx
Padding
Margin
Item 1

title: Forms
description: Learn how to build accessible forms with FlexiUI components.

body.raw:
# Forms

FlexiUI provides form components built on React Aria, ensuring accessibility and proper form handling out of the box.

## Basic Form

Create a simple form using FlexiUI components:

```tsx
import { Form } from '@flexi-ui/form'
import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input'
import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button'

function ContactForm() {
  return (
    <Form onSubmit={(e) => {
      e.preventDefault()
      // Handle form submission
    }}>
      <Input
        label="Name"
        name="name"
        isRequired
      />
      <Input
        label="Email"
        name="email"
        type="email"
        isRequired
      />
      <Button type="submit">
        Submit
      </Button>
    </Form>
  )
}
```

## Form Validation

FlexiUI components support native HTML5 validation and custom validation:

```tsx
<Input
  label="Email"
  type="email"
  isRequired
  errorMessage="Please enter a valid email"
/>
```

## Controlled Forms

Use controlled inputs with state:

```tsx
import { useState } from 'react'
import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input'

function ControlledForm() {
  const [value, setValue] = useState('')

  return (
    <Input
      label="Username"
      value={value}
      onChange={(e) => setValue(e.target.value)}
    />
  )
}
```

## Form Libraries

FlexiUI works with popular form libraries like React Hook Form and Formik:

```tsx
import { useForm } from 'react-hook-form'
import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input'
import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button'

function HookFormExample() {
  const { register, handleSubmit } = useForm()

  return (
    <form onSubmit={handleSubmit(data => console.log(data))}>
      <Input
        label="Name"
        {...register('name', { required: true })}
      />
      <Button type="submit">Submit</Button>
    </form>
  )
}
```

description: Learn how to install FlexiUI in your project.

body.raw:
# Installation Get started with FlexiUI by installing it in your React project. ## Prerequisites Before you begin, make sure you have the following installed: - Node.js 18.x or higher - React 18 or React 19 - Tailwind CSS 4.x ## Install FlexiUI Install FlexiUI and its dependencies using your preferred package manager: ### npm ```bash npm install @flexi-ui/react @flexi-ui/theme ``` ### pnpm ```bash pnpm add @flexi-ui/react @flexi-ui/theme ``` ### yarn ```bash yarn add @flexi-ui/react @flexi-ui/theme ``` ## Tailwind CSS Setup FlexiUI is built on top of Tailwind CSS. Add the FlexiUI plugin to your Tailwind configuration: ### tailwind.config.js ```javascript import { flexiui } from '@flexi-ui/theme' /** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ export default { content: [ './app/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}', './components/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}', './node_modules/@flexi-ui/theme/dist/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}', ], theme: { extend: {}, }, plugins: [flexiui()], } ``` ## Provider Setup Wrap your application with the FlexiUIProvider: ```tsx import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/system' export default function App({ Component, pageProps }) { return ( ) } ``` ## Using Components Now you can import and use FlexiUI components in your application: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' export default function Home() { return (
) } ``` ## Next Steps - [Learn about routing integration](/docs/guide/routing) - [Customize your theme](/docs/customization/theme) - [Explore components](/docs/components/button)

title: Introduction
description: Get started with FlexiUI, a modern React UI library.

body.raw:
# Introduction Welcome to FlexiUI - a beautiful, fast, and modern React UI library. ## What is FlexiUI? FlexiUI is a modern, open-source React UI library that provides a comprehensive set of accessible, customizable components with a powerful theming system built on Tailwind CSS. Whether you're building a simple landing page or a complex web application, FlexiUI provides all the tools you need to create beautiful, accessible, and performant user interfaces. ## Key Features - **Themeable:** Customize every component with our powerful theme system built on Tailwind CSS - **Accessible:** Built on React Aria for world-class accessibility with keyboard navigation and screen reader support - **TypeScript:** Fully typed with comprehensive IntelliSense support - **Fast & Lightweight:** Optimized bundle size with tree-shaking support - **Responsive:** Mobile-first design that works seamlessly across all devices - **Modular:** Import only what you need for maximum flexibility ## Why FlexiUI? FlexiUI stands out from other UI libraries by focusing on three core principles: - **Developer Experience:** Intuitive API, comprehensive documentation, and excellent TypeScript support - **Accessibility First:** Every component is built with accessibility in mind from the ground up - **Performance:** Optimized for speed with minimal bundle size and maximum flexibility ## Getting Started Ready to start building? Check out our installation guide to get FlexiUI set up in your project.
Installation Guide Browse Components
## Community & Support FlexiUI is open source and built by a community of developers. We welcome contributions, bug reports, and feature requests! - [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/flexi-ui/flexi-ui) - [Report Issues](https://github.com/flexi-ui/flexi-ui/issues)

title: Routing
description: Learn how to use FlexiUI with client-side routing libraries.

body.raw:
# Routing FlexiUI works seamlessly with all popular React routing solutions, including Next.js App Router, React Router, and Remix. ## Next.js App Router FlexiUI components are fully compatible with Next.js 13+ App Router: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Link } from '@flexi-ui/link' export default function Page() { return (
About
) } ``` ## React Router Use FlexiUI components with React Router: ```tsx import { Link as RouterLink } from 'react-router-dom' import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' function App() { return ( ) } ``` ## Remix FlexiUI integrates smoothly with Remix: ```tsx import { Link as RemixLink } from '@remix-run/react' import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' export default function Index() { return ( ) } ``` ## Client-Side Navigation All FlexiUI components support the `as` prop, allowing you to use them with any routing library while maintaining their styling and behavior.

title: Tailwind CSS v4
description: Migrate your FlexiUI project to Tailwind CSS v4.

body.raw:
# Tailwind CSS v4

FlexiUI is built to work seamlessly with Tailwind CSS v4, leveraging the latest features and improvements.

## What's New in v4

Tailwind CSS v4 introduces several improvements:

- **Lightning-fast engine** - Rebuilt from the ground up in Rust
- **Unified toolchain** - Single package for all features
- **CSS-first configuration** - Configure using CSS variables
- **Improved IntelliSense** - Better autocomplete and suggestions

## Migration Guide

### Update Dependencies

Update your `package.json`:

```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "tailwindcss": "^4.0.0"
  }
}
```

### Configuration

Tailwind v4 uses CSS-first configuration. Update your `tailwind.config.ts`:

```ts
import type { Config } from 'tailwindcss'

const config: Config = {
  content: [
    './app/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}',
    './components/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}',
    './node_modules/@flexi-ui/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}'
  ],
  theme: {
    extend: {}
  }
}

export default config
```

### CSS Variables

Use CSS variables for theming:

```css
@theme {
  --color-primary: #0070f3;
  --color-secondary: #7928ca;
}
```

## FlexiUI Compatibility

FlexiUI is fully compatible with Tailwind CSS v4. All components work without any changes required.

## Performance Benefits

Tailwind CSS v4 offers significant performance improvements:

- **10x faster** builds compared to v3
- **Smaller bundle sizes** with automatic tree-shaking
- **Better DX** with instant feedback in development

## Resources

- [Tailwind CSS v4 Documentation](https://tailwindcss.com/docs)
- [Migration Guide](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/upgrade-guide)
- [FlexiUI Examples](https://github.com/flexi-ui/flexi-ui/tree/main/examples)

title: Astro
description: Learn how to use FlexiUI with Astro.

body.raw:
# Astro FlexiUI can be used with Astro to create interactive islands within your static site. ## Create a New Project Create a new Astro project: ```bash pnpm create astro@latest my-app cd my-app ``` ## Installation Install FlexiUI and the React integration: ```bash pnpm add @flexi-ui/react pnpm astro add react tailwind ``` ## Configure Astro Update `astro.config.mjs`: ```js import { defineConfig } from 'astro/config' import react from '@astrojs/react' import tailwind from '@astrojs/tailwind' export default defineConfig({ integrations: [react(), tailwind()] }) ``` ## Configure Tailwind Update `tailwind.config.mjs`: ```js /** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ export default { content: [ './src/**/*.{astro,html,js,jsx,md,mdx,svelte,ts,tsx,vue}', './node_modules/@flexi-ui/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}' ], plugins: [require('@flexi-ui/tailwind-plugin')] } ``` ## Create a Provider Component Create `src/components/Providers.tsx`: ```tsx import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' export function Providers({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return {children} } ``` ## Create Interactive Components Create `src/components/ContactForm.tsx`: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input' import { Providers } from './Providers' export function ContactForm() { return (
) } ``` ## Use in Astro Pages Use the component in your Astro page: ```astro --- import { ContactForm } from '../components/ContactForm' --- FlexiUI + Astro

Contact Us

``` ## Client Directives Use Astro's client directives to control hydration: - `client:load` - Hydrate immediately - `client:idle` - Hydrate when the page is idle - `client:visible` - Hydrate when the component is visible - `client:only` - Only render on the client ```astro ``` ## Static Site Generation FlexiUI components integrate seamlessly with Astro's SSG capabilities, providing interactive elements within your static pages.

title: Next.js
description: Learn how to use FlexiUI with Next.js.

body.raw:
# Next.js FlexiUI works seamlessly with Next.js, supporting both the Pages Router and App Router. ## Installation Install FlexiUI in your Next.js project: ```bash pnpm add @flexi-ui/react ``` ## Setup with App Router Configure FlexiUI with the App Router (Next.js 13+): ### 1. Create a Provider Component Create `app/providers.tsx`: ```tsx 'use client' import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' export function Providers({ children }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return ( {children} ) } ``` ### 2. Wrap Your App Update `app/layout.tsx`: ```tsx import { Providers } from './providers' export default function RootLayout({ children, }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return ( {children} ) } ``` ### 3. Configure Tailwind CSS Update `tailwind.config.ts`: ```ts import type { Config } from 'tailwindcss' const config: Config = { content: [ './app/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}', './components/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx,mdx}', './node_modules/@flexi-ui/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}' ], plugins: [require('@flexi-ui/tailwind-plugin')] } export default config ``` ## Setup with Pages Router For the Pages Router (Next.js 12 and below): ### 1. Update _app.tsx ```tsx import type { AppProps } from 'next/app' import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' export default function App({ Component, pageProps }: AppProps) { return ( ) } ``` ## Using Components Import and use FlexiUI components: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input' export default function Page() { return (
) } ``` ## Server Components FlexiUI components are client components. Mark them with `'use client'` when needed: ```tsx 'use client' import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' export function ClientComponent() { return } ``` ## TypeScript FlexiUI provides full TypeScript support out of the box.

title: Remix
description: Learn how to use FlexiUI with Remix.

body.raw:
# Remix FlexiUI works perfectly with Remix, providing a great developer experience with server-side rendering. ## Create a New Project Create a new Remix project: ```bash npx create-remix@latest my-app cd my-app ``` ## Installation Install FlexiUI: ```bash pnpm add @flexi-ui/react ``` ## Setup Tailwind CSS ### 1. Install Tailwind ```bash pnpm add -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer npx tailwindcss init -p ``` ### 2. Configure Tailwind Update `tailwind.config.ts`: ```ts import type { Config } from 'tailwindcss' export default { content: [ './app/**/*.{js,jsx,ts,tsx}', './node_modules/@flexi-ui/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}' ], plugins: [require('@flexi-ui/tailwind-plugin')] } satisfies Config ``` ### 3. Add Tailwind Directives Create `app/tailwind.css`: ```css @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; ``` ### 4. Import Styles Update `app/root.tsx`: ```tsx import type { LinksFunction } from '@remix-run/node' import stylesheet from '~/tailwind.css' export const links: LinksFunction = () => [ { rel: 'stylesheet', href: stylesheet } ] ``` ## Setup FlexiUI Provider Update `app/root.tsx`: ```tsx import { Links, LiveReload, Meta, Outlet, Scripts, ScrollRestoration } from '@remix-run/react' import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' export default function App() { return ( ) } ``` ## Using Components Create a route with FlexiUI components: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input' import { Form } from '@remix-run/react' export default function Index() { return (

FlexiUI + Remix

) } ``` ## Server-Side Rendering FlexiUI components work seamlessly with Remix's SSR. The provider handles hydration automatically. ## TypeScript FlexiUI provides full TypeScript support for Remix projects.

title: Vite
description: Learn how to use FlexiUI with Vite.

body.raw:
# Vite FlexiUI integrates seamlessly with Vite for blazing-fast development. ## Create a New Project Create a new Vite + React project: ```bash pnpm create vite my-app --template react-ts cd my-app ``` ## Installation Install FlexiUI and its peer dependencies: ```bash pnpm add @flexi-ui/react pnpm add -D tailwindcss postcss autoprefixer ``` ## Setup Tailwind CSS ### 1. Initialize Tailwind ```bash npx tailwindcss init -p ``` ### 2. Configure Tailwind Update `tailwind.config.js`: ```js /** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ export default { content: [ './index.html', './src/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}', './node_modules/@flexi-ui/**/*.{js,ts,jsx,tsx}' ], plugins: [require('@flexi-ui/tailwind-plugin')] } ``` ### 3. Add Tailwind Directives Create or update `src/index.css`: ```css @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; ``` ## Setup FlexiUI Provider Update `src/main.tsx`: ```tsx import React from 'react' import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client' import { FlexiUIProvider } from '@flexi-ui/react' import App from './App' import './index.css' ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')!).render( ) ``` ## Using Components Import and use FlexiUI components in your app: ```tsx import { Button } from '@flexi-ui/button' import { Input } from '@flexi-ui/input' function App() { return (

FlexiUI + Vite

) } export default App ``` ## Development Start the development server: ```bash pnpm dev ``` ## Build for Production Build your app for production: ```bash pnpm build ``` ## Vite Configuration Optimize your Vite configuration for FlexiUI: ```ts import { defineConfig } from 'vite' import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react' export default defineConfig({ plugins: [react()], optimizeDeps: { include: ['@flexi-ui/react'] } }) ```
